(CBS) QUOTE OF THE DAY
“You can fool some of the people all of the time, and all of the 
      people some of the time, but you can not fool all of the people all of the 
      time.” - Abraham Lincoln 

TODAY’S TRIVIA Ancient Chinese artists would never paint 
      pictures of women's feet. 

TONIGHT ON THE CBS 
      EVENING NEWS Here's an early look 
      at what we are working on from Anchor and Managing Editor, Katie Couric 
      Hi everyone, This May Day was a day of protest for 
      U.S. immigrants. Demonstrators in cities from Los Angeles to Milwaukee to 
      New York demanded a path to citizenship for the estimated 12 million 
      illegal immigrants – and want to do so before the 2008 election dominates 
      the political zeitgeist. Bill Whitaker will have more on the 
      protests and Sandra Hughes will show us the impact of U.S raids on 
      immigrants in one family. May Day took on a different meaning in 
      Cuba. There was much talk yesterday – and plenty of anticipation today – 
      of Cuban leader Fidel Castro appearing at Havana’s May Day celebrations. 
      But as hundreds of thousands of Cubans marched through the streets, there 
      was no sign of Castro. Our chief foreign correspondent Lara Logan 
      will report on what that could mean. Even before Congress approved 
      the Iraq spending legislation calling for troop withdrawal, President Bush 
      threatened that it would meet his veto pen should it cross his desk. 
      Jim Axelrod will have the very latest on what happened today when 
      the president got the bill. Continuing our series, “Caught in the 
      Web,” Daniel Sieberg will take a look at the growing obsession with 
      Internet pornography, and how viewing it can be addictive. He’ll talk to 
      one family that overcame an addiction – and also look at an innovative way 
      to confront the problem. Twenty Texas teenagers who died from a 
      cocktail of crushed nighttime pain relievers and black-tar heroin seemed 
      to know they were doing something illegal, but didn’t realize it was also 
      highly addictive and could be deadly. Kelly Cobiella will report on 
      the schoolyard high called “cheese.” And as spring comes to the 
      Middle East, so comes spring fashion to Tehran, Iran. And with new styles 
      come the fashion police – really. With hardliners in power, the crackdown 
      on non-Islamic styles is harsher than ever. Elizabeth Palmer will 
      have the inside story from Iranian woman. I hope you’ll join us. 
      Katie For more on two of the stories noted above, please 
      click on the following links: Immigration Rallies Hit U.S. 
      Streets Click Here Bush Ready To Veto 
      Iraq Bill Click Here Here's a look at one 
      of the stories we are working on for Wednesday's broadcast of the CBS 
      EVENING NEWS... Millions of parents worry their kids spend too much 
      time on the internet.We'll go halfway around the world to tell you what 
      ONE country is doing about it. The conclusion of our series, "Caught in 
      the Web,"... and a lot more--Wednesday night on the CBS EVENING NEWS. 
      If you would like more information on the broadcast, please click 
      on the following address and e-mail us: evening@cbsnews.com 
      

TONIGHT ON DAVID LETTERMAN Actor Tobey Maguire 
      will join Dave tonight along with impressionist John Byner… Plus, 
      musical guests Modest Mouse! 

WEDNESDAY MORNING ON THE EARLY SHOW Harry Smith, 
      Hannah Storm, Julie Chen and Russ Mitchell anchor 
      THE EARLY SHOW from New York. Dave 
      Price will bring us the weather. Along with the top news of 
      the day, we will also have the following stories: BIPOLAR 
      KIDS: The brain is one of the biggest mysteries in the human body, and 
      doctors are still in the beginning stages of diagnosing and understanding 
      mental illness, particularly among children. But as EARLY 
      SHOW National Correspondent Tracy Smith 
      reports, doctors have come to realize that some of the symptoms of these 
      brain disorders can show up at very young ages. One of the fastest growing 
      diagnoses for children is bipolar disorder, a mental illness that creates 
      extreme mood swings - highs and lows that are so debilitating these kids 
      can't just "snap out of it". It affects their ability to go to school, to 
      make friends, and to have a happy home life. Tracy visited the Abaspour 
      family in Plymouth, Massachusetts to find out what it is like to deal with 
      bipolar disorder day in and day out. THE QUEEN THEN AND 
      NOW: This week, the Queen will make her fourth state visit to the 
      United States. But this isn’t the same Queen that has visited us in years 
      past. She has undergone some re-invention lately. CBS News Correspondent 
      Mark Phillips will explain what has changed this Queen’s heart. 
      PREVENTING SEXLESS MARRIAGES: When two people fall in love 
      and get married, they typically assume their lives will be full of 
      physical intimacy. But what happens when the sex stops? Can a marriage 
      survive without it? CBS News Correspondent Susan McGinnis found out 
      from Joe and Christine Farahat, a couple who faced that very question. Dr. 
      Lana Holstein and Dr. David Taylor, who run a number of programs at 
      Miraval spa near Tucson, Arizona, will join us Wednesday morning with 
      advice on how to improve your sex life. THE GRASS IS GREENER: 
      LAWNMOWERS: All over the country, lawn mowers are being pulled out of 
      garages after a long winter's rest. And if you are looking to maintain a 
      pristine lawn this year, you’ll need the right equipment to get the job 
      done. Wednesday morning, our friend, Danny Lipford, will join us 
      with advice on how you can keep your lawn mower in good working condition 
      and tips that will help keep your lawn looking picture perfect. 
      MORE MAGAZINE: DUTIFUL DAUGHTERS: Most parents, especially 
      moms, feel they owe it to their children to help finance an education, but 
      the decision to save for kids college could be a costly one. Barbara 
      O'Dair, Executive Editor of More magazine, says that if you put 
      saving for college before saving for retirement, your kids may be 
      responsible for taking care of you in your old age. O’Dair will join us 
      Wednesday morning with advice. CHIC ON A SHOESTRING: WEARING 
      THE LATEST IN SACK DRESSES: Warmer weather is finally here and what a 
      great time to add some new, fashionable items to your closet. Even if you 
      are tight on closet space or cash, have no fear because Mudle 
      Claire magazine's Editor-in-Chief Joanna Coles will join us with looks 
      that are sure to be easy on your wallet and will have you looking stylish 
      from now until early fall. WILLIAMS SONOMA: AVOCADOES: If 
      you love guacamole, you can thank the Spanish conquistadors for 
      introducing the world to avocados once they discovered them in South 
      America. Wednesday morning, our friend, cookbook author Tori 
      Ritchie will join us with some amazing recipes featuring this fruit 
      that will show you its incredible versatility. If you would like 
      more information on any of these stories or the broadcast, please click on 
      the following address and e-mail us: earlyshow@cbs.com
